block.p: Germany Proposes Union In a European Federation Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's governing party proposed a far-reaching plan to turn the European Union into a more centralized federal system. The plan, modeled after the structure of Germany, would give much more power to the European Parliament, but it is expected to cause national anxiety in Britain and France.

The plan, modeled after the structure of Germany, would give much more power to the European Parliament, but it is expected to cause national anxiety in Britain and France.

Risks in Returning to China The State Security Ministry has recently been detaining American citizens born in China and questioning them about their affairs in China, criticism of the government or links to Taiwan, in what diplomats see as a worrisome change in policy.

Bush Promotes Missile System President Bush called leaders of several European and Asian allies to pave the diplomatic way for his plan for a missile defense system and the possibility of renouncing the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. His calls were in advance of a speech on missile defense he is to give today.

Indonesia Leader Under Fire An angry Parliament voted, 363 to 52, with 42 abstentions, to censure President Abdurrahman Wahid for corruption and incompetence, taking a big step toward impeachment proceedings and heightening calls for his resignation.

Violence in Manila Backers of the ousted Filipino president, Joseph Estrada, marched on the presidential palace to demand that his successor resign, and were met with gunfire and tear gas. Four deaths were reported. The widening protest came shortly after President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo said a coup threat had failed for lack of support.

Zambia Leader Nominated President Frederick Chiluba won his party's nomination for a third term, even as outrage mounted among some of his party's leaders. Zambia's Constitution bars a third presidential term, and Parliament would have to amend it for Mr. Chiluba to run in elections this year.

Cheney Says U.S. Will Favor Supply Over Conservation Vice President Dick Cheney said that oil, coal and natural gas would remain America's primary energy resources for ''years down the road'' and that Bush administration strategy was to aim mainly to increase supply of fossil fuels, rather than limit demand.

Most Democrats Send Regrets President Bush marked his first 100 days in office with a luncheon for all 535 members of Congress, but only about a third showed up, and the political parties squabbled over the value of the bipartisan outing.

Pledges to Denise Rich Charity Shortly before they received pardons from President Bill Clinton, Marc Rich and his business partner, Pincus Green, promised to donate $1 million a year to a cancer charity run by Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise Rich, lawyers familiar with the arrangement say. Ms. Rich played a crucial role in the campaign for clemency.

Action on Painkiller Abuse Federal officials have urged Purdue Pharma, maker of the widely abused narcotic painkiller OxyContin, to limit how it distributes and markets the drug, which has played a role in more than 100 fatal overdoses in several states.

Rush at Green Card Deadline Lines swelled at immigration offices in advance of a midnight deadline last night for taking advantage of a program that allows those with family or employer sponsors to apply for legal status in the United States without leaving the country.

Puerto Rico Range Reopens Nonexplosive shells from a cruiser and bombs from a fighter jet fell on the Navy's firing range on Vieques as exercises resumed after a one-day halt prompted by a search for protesters hiding in the fields of fire.
Some New York political leaders will join the protests in Puerto Rico.

A.C.L.U. Names New Leader Anthony D. Romero, a gay 35-year-old lawyer who has been an executive at the Ford Foundation for the last nine years, will become executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in September, succeeding the retiring Ira Glasser.

I.N.S. Officials See Signs of Possible Profiling Senior immigration officials say the Immigration and Naturalization Service's New York district, which covers New York City and Long Island, may have violated the agency's own guidelines for avoiding ethnic or racial profiling in conducting searches for illegal immigrants.

Rent Chief's Fiery Resignation The chairman of the City Rent Guidelines Board, Edward S. Hochman, who was facing ouster by Mayor Giuliani, quit and then delivered a scathing attack on the mayor, saying he was ''a control freak'' who ''browbeat'' and ''dictated to'' the board and harmed the rent-setting process.

Sentence in Parade Assault David Garcia, 33, who was convicted in the mob attacks on women in Central Park after the last National Puerto Rican Day Parade, was sentenced to a minimum of two and a half years in prison, despite pleas for mercy and denials of wrongdoing.

Girl Reports Rape in School Three teenagers were arrested after two of them raped a 14-year-old girl in a stairwell at Intermediate School 158 in the Morrisania section of the Bronx while the third acted as lookout, the police said.
A Dolphin, on Reflection Two unrelated studies report that dolphins can recognize themselves in mirrors and interpret the intentions of others, in this case, humans.
Meyer Friedman An originator of the theory linking heart attacks to impatient, angry ''Type A'' behavior, he was 90.
From Free to Fee A growing number of Web sites that once offered goods, services or content for free now charge users.

Child Product Safety Concerns The government will announce today the recall of a combination infant carrier and car seat made by Evenflo that has injured 97 children. It is the latest in a series of product failures leading consumer advocates to worry that multipurpose baby products sometimes compromise safety.

Company Defends Accounting Computer Associates said its accounting conformed to standard rules and that it had not inflated its results, a day after The New York Times reported that former employees and analysts had raised serious questions about the company's financial statements. Shares of Computer Associates fell 8.7 percent on the report, closing at $32.19, down $3.06.
